content: @WG-async-sprint-planning we have a sprint planning meeting in ~40 minutes
Sorry, I'm feeling a bit covid-y this afternoon and won't be able to make it
I hope you feel better!
I need to run out, I'm going to miss this :(
hmm did I break the async foundations website? I got an email that the CI failed
hm I'll have to check
@WG-async-sprint-planning okay, time for our meeting
I expect this one will be shorter, since we cancelled the last sprint

Agenda

  • Assign polish issues
  • Identify sprint goals
First of all, happy new year :)
I hope everyone who went on vacation / staycation had a good break
This is doc, right? : https://hackmd.io/gPgXC4fsTZOgOnd-Bwhoag?both#2021-12-09
yes, thanks
okay, we can get started with the agenda
Polish issues
Here's the project board if you need to look at it
I'm likely carrying forward some of my work from before
:time_ticking: let's take time to update the doc
God I think I get this backwards every tmie
Am I supposed to be filling in my past status on the agenda from last time?
and my goals on the agenda for this week?
yes
Or does both status/progress and goals for next sprint go into agenda for this week?
okay
let me try to fix that, I guess
I'm definitely open to suggestions for making it clearer or taking a different approach

(Its counter-intutive to me because I don’t expect people to look at the agenda for last meeting. But maybe that’s okay, because progress/status is not as important during meeting; what is important is goals for upcoming sprint, is that right?)
Ah yeah, I guess I've been thinking more of each section as the section for that sprint as opposed to specifically that meeting
Maybe by marking the headers as "Sprint beginning YYYY-MM-DD" that would be more intuitive?
I don’t know. I think part of my problem is that I know the text tagged with a date was generated on that date
and so I sometimes feel a little weird adding on to it two weeks later
maybe I wouldn’t feel weird if i were updating it during teh whole sprint
For me the scrolling back and forth gets tricky. It's easier to lose track of where I am. Although all the ideas I can think of (e.g. a different doc per sprint) seem strictly worse.
Also, I wasn’t being facetious about when I said “Maybe reporting progress isn’t as important."
i.e. if something really big happens, then sure, we can make mention of it (especially in the sprint retrospective at the top of the meeting).
but then again, if we don’t report progress, then it might be hard to understand the flow from sprint to sprint
I sometimes go and update the doc between meetings but yeah, generally don't
I’m sorry I’m distracting us with this meta-issue
nah it's fine, this is usually when we have the retrospective
(the first part of the meeting, I mean)
I've found it helpful to review the sprint doc between sprint meetings. It helps me when I'm deciding what to work on to at least say "a week ago I thought this would be important"
yes, I've been copying those sprint goals into another doc for my initiative specifically that I look at at least 2x/week

I think the advantage of reporting progress is

  • having a record of what got done (for general accomplishment sake, plus having something to refer back to)
  • calibrating sprint goals
So I have no tooling goals at the moment
I could go find tokio-console TODO's
I would say it's not for accountability or "proving" you did stuff to others
but I’m thinking there’s likely other stuff that needs more love
though it is useful for me to look back and see what we accomplished as a group
Maybe I should e.g. reach out to @mw and see if I can assist with their crash-dump debugging initiative?
we should officially move on to the next agenda item :)
(that would probably align well with other debuginfo/debugging-related work I have going on)
Sprint goals
Okay, now I’ll formally ask my Q again. :)

pnkfelix said:

Maybe I should e.g. reach out to mw and see if I can assist with their crash-dump debugging initiative?

that sounds good
Anyone want to try to influence what I write down under the “Tooling” section?
I think for tooling you can be an effective area owner by enabling / providing "backup" to the various initiatives
and direction when needed
but they are fairly distinct efforts with strong ownership
which is a good thing, I think
anyway, :time_ticking: goes to update the doc
I think the goals I'm carrying over from last sprint are a bit too broad
okay, I restricted their scope some
I think we're done?
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
ok

General

  • [ ] (nikomatsakis/tmandry) year end blog post summarizing async wg state
it can still be a year end blog post at the beginning of the next year :)

Async fundamentals

  • [ ] Post outline for dyn strategy: "A tale of two dyns"
  • [ ] Make RPIT use a type alias to a type defined in body's function
  • [ ] Draft a new RFC incorporating RPITIT and naming function output types

Polish

Goals:

  • [ ] Experiment with trimmed backtraces
    - [ ] Crate that supports more flexible backtrace filtering (include/exclude function/module names)
    - [ ] Publish examples of trimmed backtraces
    - [ ] Stretch: Proc macro to annotate functions/modules as not being included in backtraces by default
  • [ ] Update must not suspend lint page to reflect current status (carry over from last sprint)

Issues: ([project board])

  • [ ] (pnkfelix) Strange async use ...; compiler suggestion #87613
    - [ ] extend Rust parser with use injection point(s) to drive suggestions
    - [ ] finish extending AST representation
    - [ ] add code to identify the injection points
    - [ ] update suggestion machinery

  • [ ] (eholk) Dropped variables still included in generator type #57478 (part of #69663)
    - [ ] Wait on and respond to code review feedback
    - [ ] Land it

  • [ ] (tmandry) E0623 highlights wrong parameter in async fn #74256
    - [ ] Get a review on #92183 and update PR
    - [ ] Write PR for first follow-up fix

Tooling

  • [ ] (pnkfelix) Reach out to mw and see what needs doing for async-crashdump.
I have been quite absent for personal reasons, but slowly getting back into it, what needs to change about the must not suspend lint page? indication that its waiting on @eholk 's pr?

Gus Wynn said:

what needs to change about the must not suspend lint page? indication that its waiting on eholk 's pr?
Oops.. forgot to actually reply
Basically, the page still has a lot of "this is what we need to do," but doesn't reflect the fact that you did a lot of awesome work and that it's mostly done.
At least, it's a good ways towards done... Mostly I just want it to be clear about what's done and what's left to do.
I was thinking for that goal @pnkfelix you could include something very general like "and contribute", but.. not sure how useful it would be :)
for the “reach out to mw goal” , you mean?
yeah
I figured that was semi-implicit.
i.e. if there’s value I can add, I’ll do so. But I also see no reason to commit to it if it won’t make sense.
that's fair
(the place where I want to keep myself honest is just in getting involved in the first place.)
sounds good
ok, is there anything left to discuss?
@triagebot end-meeting

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.
My goals feel smaller this time (I intentionally didn't carry some forward), but hopefully I'll get a better sense of calibration going forward
Obviously not everyone could make it today, so: please update your sprint goals asynchronously
Thanks everyone! :wave:
Thanks, @tmandry !

eholk said:

Basically, the page still has a lot of "this is what we need to do," but doesn't reflect the fact that you did a lot of awesome work and that it's mostly done.

I can put up a pr to update that if you want! Unless you or someone else wanted to already!

Gus Wynn said:

eholk said:

Basically, the page still has a lot of "this is what we need to do," but doesn't reflect the fact that you did a lot of awesome work and that it's mostly done.

I can put up a pr to update that if you want! Unless you or someone else wanted to already!

Yeah, that'd be awesome! I'll be happy to review and merge it for you!
ack!!! sorry y'all
I had an overlapping meeting
will catch up

Hey everyone! Crashdump debugging is making progress in the sense that

  • I've been collecting general debuginfo-fidelity issues that need fixing (type names of generic closures and generators are broken, raw fat pointers are broken, scoping of local variables does not work correctly in some cases)
  • the testing runner is making progress. It's quite usable for writing normal debuginfo tests and soon should have support for generating and testing crashdumps too.
